Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a means for the government to control and suppress dissenting opinions.
The bill is compared to historical instances of censorship and authoritarian control, such as pre-World War II Germany.
The legislation is perceived as an attack on free speech and capitalist beliefs.
Concerns are raised about the potential for increased surveillance and censorship similar to 'techno-Stasi' police state laws.
The bill is viewed as part of a broader global agenda to control information and suppress dissent.
Main Themes: Comparison to historical and global events
Notable Quotes: The Government wants more control over anyone who discusses any matter that the Government does not like, this has the smell of what took place in Germany in prior to Hitler coming to power.
This is an attack on our capitalist beliefsâ€¦.i.e. free will and free speech.
Unbeknownst to most Australians, our country in recent years has been leading the world in the adoption of Stasi-like surveillance and spying laws which threaten basic human freedoms.
